Replies.Reply: Winds in the East Mist coming in--
--Like something is brewing, about to begin--
Excuse me ma'am, have you seen my daughter? I was quite sure I had left her around here somewhere!
Her name is Helen, no, Shirley, erm-
You're right still doesn't sound quite-- I'm sure I have a special name for her--
Why, thank you ma'am! Ginty it is of course!
Gosh! So it is! Well, thank goodness for that! I was positive I was going to be beheaded for losing Her Highness The Royal Princess Ginty Mc Featherfluffy!
Never. I promise. I will never lose you!
Hurry now! We mustn't be late! The adventure is about to begin!
Who needs a carriage my love? A stroll is a gift!
Come along my team! We mustn't miss the train.
Left, right, left, right! Coming through!
A palace! Complete with mighty steed.
We'll build beautiful memories here my angel.
--in this house you get to share a bedroom!
I'll make us a good life.
That's it Albert. Give Ginty a smooch. There's a good boy, give her a little smooch.
Poor old Albert; he's your secret uncle you know? But a miserable, horrid witch turned him into a nag.
Because she hated the sound of his laugh.
We have to teach the witch how to be happy again.
Your mother's been calling you for a good hour. I shouldn't go if I were you, she's after little slaves for housework!
Do you want to know what it feels like to fly Ginty?
Swish! Which kind of kisses do you prefer Gintamina? Swoosh! Scratchy ones or silky ones?
Replies.Didascalie: (he flicks the blade in the air like a swordsman)

Replies.Reply: And Mr Belhatchett has complained that I opened his stupid bank five minutes late has he? Hahaaa!
Time's Money, Goff, y'know! Time's money my man!
There, whack! That'll teach you for not dropping your bairns on schedule. Whack! Whack! Whack!
Sweet thing! What are you doing here?
Ice cream day! Yes! I did! What kind of father am I?
Ah, yes it does seem that--
Just wait in my office for a second darling.
Ice cream is so rare because it only comes from Siberian cows. Did you know that?!
We share a Celtic soul, you and I.
I couldn't stop thinking about my beautiful girls on this beautiful day in this beautiful place and I thought to hell with it!
And what do we say about beauty ladies?
Buts are for goats my love!
I'll put in extra hours tomorrow.
That's no hen! That's Aunt Ellie, your mother's horrendiferous sister!
I'll wash them again my love!
Go Sergeant Ginty! Fell the beast!
--Meg sweet, I had a throat scratch-
God no! No. I can endure. I will endure. For the girl's sake-- Just, please-- not Ellie.
The world is an illusion Ginty.
Indeed! I can see the feathers sprouting as we speak!
She can't possibly lay a table; she's busy laying eggs!
Don't you ever stop dreaming Ginty my love. You can be anyone you want to be. Anyone.
Don't leave yourself always searching for-- something--
Oh, for Gods' sake, Meg, stop whinnying like an old nag will you?
Meet you there in a blink of an eye!
In a moment, my princess. I'm talking.
Good afternoon, distinguished guests, our biggest supporter Mr Randolph Belhatchett and his lovely wife, ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls!

I'm honoured to be here on behalf of the Belhatchett Bank of Australia. Shortly, it will be my very pleasant duty to present the awards to our young performers. But before I begin, I'd like to say a very few words to our very youngest citizens about the role of the -
Uhmm. Thank you kindly. Thanking you. Now-- what, what am I doing next? Oh! It's a marvellous idea to encourage children to open accounts. My daughter, the Princess Ginty-- she's-- uh.
How old are you? Come up here.
Ginty has a bank account-- and that's good. Give her a drink!
I mean give her a hand.
I shall return in just a moment to present the awards. But right now I must-- relieve myself.
Give us your shoulder, Ginty, will you? I'm busting. There's a good girl.
I don't suppose there's any more you can give me for the pain?
Be a darling Ginty my old pal! Help father out won't you?
In my washroom-- there's a bottle of medicine that father needs--
Look at you-- all ship shape.
Never. I promise. I will never lose you.
Winds in the East Mist coming in--
--Like something is brewing, about to begin--
Downwards and downwards until it skittishly circles a large, bustling park and then swoops us into the lavish gardens.
Her little brow is furrowed with imagination and then, all of a sudden, the smile breaks free as something in her mind becomes real.
The car should be here, may I use--
Why would you cancel the car?
You made an agreement. Do you understand? A verbal agreement.
I like to think of it, believe me I know it's not reciprocated.

I would never suggest you do something that would cause you anguish but there's no more money Pamela-- Mrs Travers. Simply no more. Sales have dried up, no more royalties. You refuse to write further books so--
Do you understand? I'm frightened that you don't understand what that means.
--We've been trying to do this deal for twenty years! He's agreed to both your stipulations. No animation, script approval-- I--
--script approval! He's never granted anything like that before!
You have only to go there and work for two weeks. Collaborate. That's it. You haven't signed the rights over, yet.
You must make it work Mrs Travers--
You don't sign the papers. He cannot make the film unless you grant the rights.
I am so pleased to hear that Mrs Travers.
So why do you keep her?
Wonderful. Should we start talking about the film rights?
Now, tell me, Have you got your tiara for the premiere?
He hasn't invited you, has he?
Mary Poppins wouldn't stand for that.
You're ready to--? Like pink clouds on sticks.
I was trying to think of what they--
With all due respect Mr Russell I am on very good terms with my own faculty and exceedingly confident in its decision making capabilities.
Why in the world are you speaking to me as if I am a neonate?
He'll what? Sue? He is most welcome to every penny I don't have.
I know what he's going to do to her-
Use her to pay my bills? If I believed in a hell I'd be sitting in its waiting room--
It's just as well. It seems I can't afford her anymore anyway!
You don't know how much she means to me.
Stop saying money! It's a filthy, disgusting word!
And if I don't like what they are doing to her?
I want to keep my house.
They've used all the space; so greedy.
I don't want it up there. I want it here, in the corresponding holding area for my assigned seat!
Will the child be a nuisance? It's an eleven hour flight.
I'm perfectly capable of-- Oh, nevermind.
It's not Mrs P.L. It's just Mrs--
Young man, if it is your wish to handle ladies garments I suggest you take employment in a launderette.
And you can stay there until you learn the art of subtlety.
Well, no, I don't suppose I do mind.
Off! That's how we deal with you.
It's not Mrs, it's-- Oh, why do I bother? We're just not going to get it right are we?
Will it be the same driver every day?
You say it like you're surprised.
I would so much rather be accountable for the rain.
Sad is entirely the wrong emotion.

Replies.Didascalie: (she makes gesture for flying over his head)

Replies.Reply: It is so discomfiting to hear a perfect stranger use my first name.
Co-script-writer. I shall certainly be having my say Mr. DiGraydi.
If indeed we ever sign off on a script.
Mary Poppins. Never ever just Mary.
A pleasure to meet you, though I fear we shan't be acquainted for too long.

These books simply do not lend themselves to chirping and prancing. No. Certainly not a musical. Now, where is Mister Disney? I'd very much like to get this started and finished as briskly as is humanly possible.
No one likes a show off.
I am perfectly capable of walking.
Would you let Mister Disney know I have arrived please?
You may. Whether I heed it or not will be another matter entirely.
Hum-- ah. It's an honour, Mister Disney.
A pot of tea would be most welc--
Gotcha indeed! Mister Disney, if you have dangled then it is at the end of a rope you have fashioned for yourself.

I was quite clear when you approached me the first time that she wasn't for sale and clear again when you approached me a year later and clear again when you approached me every annum for the subsequent 18 years. Honestly, I feel corralled, ensnared--
My name, if you please, is MRS Travers.
Yes, this singing, I am glad you've come to that.
You don't mean for this film to be a musical?
Not bad. No, Mister Disney, Mary Poppins does not sing.
Those aren't songs! They're recitations. She is not a giddy woman, she does not jig! Singing is frivolous and wholly unnecessary for a governess, an educatress. No.
I won't have her turned into one of your silly cartoons.
If you're the King of England then you shan't exist and knowing the little of you I do; I shouldn't think you would like that very much.
Come to think of it. That's a song I wouldn't object to.
A live action film. No animation.
Your promise-- and all the discussions we have here-- on tape.
Mary Poppins and the Banks's, they're family to me.
Let's see if that's at all possible.
We could save a starving country with benefaction from this room alone! Ugh, It's so vulgar.

And these are beautiful blooms butchered for our visual and nasal enjoyment when we could have just as easily gone to the window, looked out and gazed upon them happily minding their own business and very much still alive.
Oh, I'm sorry Mr DaGradi, did you feel you should--?
Yes, I do think it's best. I've the most practise. Readings of my books you know? Anyway--
Scene one. Exterior. 17 Cherry Tree Lane, London. Day.
Yes. That's good, that can stay.
--Though I do think we should say number 17, instead of just 17, yes?
Write it down, write it down, chop chop.
Do you think you are a comedienne?
Scene One. Exterior. Number 17 Cherry Tree Lane. London. Day.
The rumour is that this is to be your Mister Van Dyke is it?
Hmmm, we'll see about that. He's totally wrong, totally and utterly.
Dick Van Dyke? Robert, my dear, Olivier is one of the greats, Burton, Guinness - greats without question.
I can assure you Dick Van Dyke is not.
Bert, a one-man band plays to a small gathering outside the gates to the park.
No no no no no no no.
I've a thought! I've always liked Ta Ra Ra Boom De Ay. Now, that would be a wonderful song for the film! Oh! And Admiral Boom could sing it! Do you see?
If you like that sort of thing.
It's too grand! The Banks family -
Do I even have to say it?
Why in the world have you made Mrs Banks a silly suffragette?
Are you calling Mrs Banks neglectful?
Being a mother is a job. A very difficult job and one that not everybody is up to, that not everybody should have taken on in the first place!
I will NOT have her called Cynthia!
No it should be something warm, a bit sexy.
Yes, that's because it's very good.
He has a set of moustaches!
I told the illustrator I didn't like the facial hair but she chose to ignore me. This is MY film and this time around I shall have MY way.
He didn't, he doesn't, Mr Banks is clean shaven!
I shan't say it again Robert.
What is wrong with his leg?
Can I expect anymore drama from anyone else?
Stop! Stop! Stop! What on earth are you talking about? Supercali--?
Well I always know what to say.
I've simply gone off the colour.
You did say I was to have final say did you not?
I understand your predicament Mr Disney, I do. I just-- hm-- I don't know what it is, I'm just suddenly very anti-red. I shan't be wearing it ever again.
I took you at your word Mr Disney and it seems my first stipulation has been denied. There will be many more, so-- perhaps we should just call it quits and I should hand you back these?
Now, If you're insisting upon this musicality you feel is SO important for my film then I suggest I hear one of your ditties.
I shall keep an open mind!
Well I simply don't know what to say. That's the worst song I've ever heard.
Thank you. Tea is a balm for the soul don't you agree?
I loathe this place, Mr Russell.

I meant heartless. I'm afraid a jumper wouldn't suffice. It's bringing up these-- it's so hot and stuffy I feel like I am being attacked. These odd dreams, like my subconscious is after me. Punishing me for entertaining the idea that I might hand her over. I am at war with myself Mr Russell.
Serves me right. Money, money, money. Bit me on the bot.
I'm sure your country doesn't have any laws about sharing a pavement.

It seems enormously patronising to me. The very sort of annoying tune you would have playing in your themed park I daresay. All giddy and carefree, encouraging children to face the world unarmed. All they need is a spoon and some sugar and a brain full of fluff and they're equipped with life's tools.

MRS Travers! My point is that, unlike yourself, Mary Poppins is the very enemy of sentiment and whimsy. She is truthful, she doesn't sugar coat the darkness in the world that these children will eventually come to know. She prepares them for it, she deals in honesty. One must clean one's room; it won't magically do it itself!
This whole script is flim flam!
You think Mary Poppins is saving the children Mr Disney?
Why did you have to make him so cruel?
And do those children write you letters, make drawings for you?
And would you tear up those gifts?

It's a dreadful thing to do! I don't understand! Why must father tear up the advertisement his children have written and throw it in the fireplace!? Why won't he mend their kite? Why have you made him so unspeakably awful?
For all the world to see, in glorious technicolor? You claim to make them live-- if that happens can't he? Can't they at least live well?
Please don't-- I'll feel like I let him down again--
It's blasphemy to drink tea from a paper cup.
All the way to England? Yes, please.
You're an impertinent man you know?
Let us say that I haven't family who'd notice whether I was halfway across the world or sitting in my living room.
Check ups are for medical practitioners no?
What can I do for you Mister Disney?
phone calls from you on any of those other evenings.
I cannot tell you how uninterested, no, positively sickened I am at the thought of going to see your dollar printing machine Mr-- Walter.
Disappointments are to the soul what the thunderstorm is to the air.
Hello? Hello? He hung up! I'm! I! I can't believe he hung up!
Where are we--? This isn't the way.
I'm sure I don't know what you're--
Little park? I haven't a clue what you're talking about.
Concentrate on the road. Always chitter chattering!
Do you always get everything you want Walter?
With the exception to the rights to my books of course!
She flew in through the window one day.
No thank you. I'm happy to watch.
Maybe in you Mister Disney, but certainly not I.
You brought me all the way out here to tell me that?
What horrors have you in store for my beautiful characters today, hm?
Yes! He fixes the kite! Oh, I love it!
us go and fly a kite.' Bob glares at her.
But I might be willing to overlook that.
Do you know you're quite right? It is beautiful. Exquisite.
Now, how in the world does Mister Disney propose to train penguins to dance?!
I've heard about his implausibly leaved trees so I assume he does have some insane penguin wrangling scheme but it does seem rather far fetched. Can you train penguins?
I would not like to take a seat thank you. I would like to--
I shall not sit in the seat of a trickster! A fraudster! A sneak!

Penguins have very much upset me Mister Disney! Animated, dancing penguins! Now, you have seduced me with the music Mr Disney, yes you have. Those Sherman boys have quite turned my head but I shall not be moved on the matter of cartoons.
You promised me. You promised me that this film would not be an animation!
Please call my driver and have him pick me up.

You shouldn't make promises you can't keep, especially to children, they hold on to them you see? And those promises they just sit there inside of them, like little doses of poison, all those broken promises, eating away forever.
The books weren't written for the children. They were written for the promise breakers.
I'm so sorry Mister Disney. To have put everyone to so much trouble.
Would you like me to sign it?
To Jane and her dearest father--
I've just this instant realized I don't know your name.
You're the only American I have ever liked, Ralph.
They all had difficulties. Jane can do anything that anyone else can do, do you understand?
Deficiencies in concentration and hyperactive behavior. Explains everything!
But, you always get what you want eventually. Isn't that right Walter?
Milk. The milk goes in first.
And whiskey. I'll have whiskey in mine.
You've come to change my mind. To beat me into submission.
Well, Where is she when I need her?
Ah! Not true then that Disney created man in his own image?
Can't say I do and as I have no plans to ever set foot on American soil again I'm afraid I never will.
I don't know what you think you know about me Walter--
I don't need to forgive my father.
Please don't screech like an alleycat!
I should think you'll have a draft very soon.
She's quite the worst maid I've ever had!
I don't know-- she reminds me of me.
I didn't receive my invitation, but I just assumed the American postal service had fallen down on the job as per usual.
That's very kind, Mr Disney. I knew you wouldn't have forgotten me.
How indeed? You did, after all, assure me that I wouldn't be disappointed.
I thought I left you in London.
Would you call me a taxi please?
No, no. It's just that-- I can't, I can't abide cartoons!
Poor Uncle Albert! How can we fix him?
The hen got out and we've been trying to catch her!
Quick! Catch her before she flies away on the--
I want to be like you.
Father-- will you ride the carousel with me!?
Father, come and look. Biddy's dancing.
But she's-- she really wants you to watch, Dad. You'll miss it.
I wrote a poem for you. It - it won first prize, at school.
Would you like me to read it to you?
Once upon a time there were three little girls alone in a house.
But the stars were guarding them, they glittered as they spoke "We shall send a guide to show them the way to the magical ladder which will bring them all the way up to  SEE US"
And who do you think those sparkling messengers sent? Who was it that came flying through the starry, starry sky to carry us up to see them?
Their old Uncle Albert of course!
I'm going to find the end of the story so I can bring it back for you!
It's time to go home, ma.
Shall I buy you something father?
I want to see my father.
You promised you would fix everything.
I'll take it Madam. I can put it up here -
The flight's closing in just a few moments Ma'am. I'll have to take it.
You can put my bag up front instead.
Thank you so much. For everything.
Biddy and Moya are already asleep.
What a lovely surprise! Did you finish early?
--the bank is getting you down again? Perhaps my sister--
Helen Goff, would you lay the table for supper please?
He is indeed! On behalf of the bank.
I'll take Biddy to get ready for her dance.
I know you gave it to him.
All the hope is in the bottom of that bottle, Helen.
I want you to take care of the children.
I know you love your father more.
Sometimes a person we love, through no fault of his own, can't see past the end of his nose.
Welcome, Mrs P.L. Travers! Welcome to the City of Angels.
Sun came out to say hello just to you.
You okay back there Mrs P.L.

No problemo! We got a brand new air conditioning system, Missus; cool you right down in no time. Just about make you feel like you're in good old Engerland again! Things they can put in cars these days--
I, uh, brought you a tea.
Everything okay Ma'am? Would you like me to drive you home?
You got family back there Mrs?
I know! I do, do that. Yes!
Jane-- she's got all kinds of troubles.
She's in a wheelchair see? That's why I concern myself with the weather-- sunny day she can sit out in the garden. Rainy day I have to leave her cooped up inside.
Hey! I wish I could take her there!
Change of venue this morning apparently.
I was thinking about our-- tea party?
Oh! Isn't that nice? Holy mackerel!
Hi! I'm such a huge fan. It's such an honour to--
The lady's ready to go now sir.
It's been a pleasure driving you Mrs.
I really have enjoyed it. Didn't know who you were at first and then guess what?
I was telling my daughter all about my day and how I was driving this nice writer lady, Mrs Travers for Mr Disney and--
Uh huh. Like the girl in the book.
Albert Einstein, Van Gogh, Roosevelt, Frida Kahlo--
Had a feeling a certain friend of mine might be needing me tonight.
You look like a million bucks!
This is your night. None of this would be possible without you.
Would you like me to unpack for you ma'am?
To take your items from their cases and hang them in the wardrobe ma'am.
Travers puts an arm around her shoulder.
SPLOSH! A green bomb disturbs the tranquil surface and then another SPLOSH!
Don't worry! There's nothing wrong with your television set. This is a pixie bell, the sound is much too high for human ears.
Hey! Get that stuff off of me!
You know, a little sprinkling of fairy dust can make you fly!
Well, there ya are at last!
You can't imagine how excited I am to finally meet you!
Tommie, say hi to the one and only P L Travers!
Ya know, I can't believe it. P.L.
Wish ya coulda' seen me then Pam!
But now, here you are. Look at you!
When Diane here was seven years old I-- can I get you a drink? Coffee?
She was seven years old and I was walking past her bedroom and there she was on her bed reading to Sharon, and well, they were just giggling their little socks off!
Tommie, pot of tea please dear--
Replies.Didascalie: (he picks up the phone, presses a button)

Replies.Reply: My imagination was caught on fire!
They're both women now. Gosh! Can you believe it?
Now Pam, a man can't break a promise to his kids. No matter how long it takes to keep. No matter how long! You might've kept me dangling all this time but now we gotcha!
Pam, Pam, the last thing I want is to make you feel--
You see, I promised them. That's a fact. You got kids?
I have never, I swear, never broken a promise to either one of my Disney girls.
That's what being a daddy is all about right?
This movie isn't just going to make my kids happy. It's going to make ALL kids happy! You see my guys are gonna do things with it that are, well, are revolutionary.
Mary Poppins will literally fly off the pages of your books!
Now imagine! This magical woman who has only lived in your head, you'll be able to meet her, speak to her, hear her sing.
Tell ya what. You just listen to what my Sherman boys have come up with and if they don't knock your socks off then I'm the King of England.
Pam, I want you to know that the last thing I would do, the very last thing, is tarnish a story I have cherished.
The pages are worn down to tissue, dog eared and falling out. I have poured over them gripped, tormented. Because I love Mary Poppins, you got to share her with me.
A course nothing happens without your say so. Absolutely Nothing.
It's all in the rights agreement.
I won't be able to stop singing that for weeks!
No whimsy or sentiment says the woman who sends a flying nanny with a talking umbrella to save the children.
She's going to say no isn't she?
I do. I know it, I know it only too well.
I've fought this battle from her side. Pat Powers, he wanted the mouse and I didn't have a bean back then.
He was this big terrifying New York producer and I was just a kid from Missouri with a sketch of Mickey but-- it woulda' killed me to give him up.
Honest to god killed me. That mouse, he's family.
Callin' to check up on you.
Pam, are you always so battle ready? P.L. Travers in her breast plate and chain mail, sword up in the air and off with your head!
Please, I beg of you, please please call me Walt.
I heard things didn't go so well today.
What's this all about Pam? Really?
I'm wondering what I have to do to make you happy.
You know, you've never been to Disneyland! It's the happiest place on Earth!
Oh come on! When does anybody get to go to Disneyland with Walt Disney himself?!
I'm not a violent man Tommie but if Mrs P.L. Travers were to get hit by a large truck I--
Okay boys. We gotta fix this.
This woman's a bona fide genius!
In Adventureland there is a tree--
It has three million leaves, four million flowers.
And they said only God could make a tree!
It's just that easy isn't it Mrs Travers?
I know you don't wanna be here so I'm gonna take you to one ride-- my favourite amusement and then I'll set you free.
Mrs Travers, I would be honoured if you would ride Jingles. She's Mrs Disney's favourite horse.
No greater joy than that seen through the eyes of a child.
There's a child in us all.
Mary Poppins, the Banks's, they're family.
The boys have had an idea for your Mister Banks. I think it'll make you happy.
No. I brought you all the way out here for monetary gain. Had a wager with the boys that I couldn't get you on a ride. I win!
Don't worry Tommie, please close the door.
Never let anybody see me smoking.
Mrs Travers, what in the world has upset you so?
Please Mrs Travers-- You must listen.
The promise breakers? Mrs Travers I-
I've been talking to the wrong person.
It was one heck of a job getting a seat on the very next flight, let me tell you.
How about you show me how to make one of those nice English pots of tea?
No, I've come because you misjudge me.
You look at me and you see some kind of Hollywood King Midas.
You think I've built an empire and that I want to use your Mary Poppins as just another brick in my kingdom. You think I see her with a carpetbag full of greenbacks.
If that was all it was would I have pursued an cranky, stubborn dame like you for twenty years? I'd've have saved myself an ulcer!

No, you expected me to disappoint you and so you made sure I did. You see, I think life disappoints you, Mrs Travers. I think it's done that a lot. Maybe Mary Poppins is the only person in your life who hasn't.
Oh, no, that's not true. She's real as can be to my daughter's and to thousands of other children--
Mrs Travers, I am so sorry. I hoped this would be a magical experience for you, for all of us. But I let you down-- and in doing so, I've broken a twenty year old promise to my girls.
I've been wracking my brains, trying to figure out why this has been so hard for you and I--
You see, I have my own Mr Banks.
But it is true that you created yourself in someone else's yes?
Ever been to Kansas City, Mrs Travers? Do you know Missouri at all?
It's mighty cold there in the winters. Bitter.
My dad, Elias Disney, he owned a newspaper delivery route there.
You'd push through it like wading through molasses.

And the cold and the wet would be seeping through the shoes and the skin would be raw and peeling from our faces-- and sometimes I'd find myself sunk down in the snow, waking up, cuz I must've passed out for a moment-- I dunno. Then school, too cold to figure out an equation. And back into the snow so by the time we got home it'd be just getting dark, and every part of you would sting like crazy as it slowly came back to life in the warmth. My mother would feed us dinner and then it'd be time to go out again for the evening edition.
Best be quick Walt, best be quick or poppa's gonna show you the buckle end again boy.
Now, I don't tell you all this to make you sad Mrs Travers, I don't.
You must've loved and admired him a lot to take his name--
Mrs. Travers. It's all about him isn't it? All of this. Everything.
Forgiveness. It's what I learned from your books.
No, you need to forgive Helen Goff.
Give her to me, Mrs Travers. Trust me with your precious Mary Poppins.
We'll premiere in London as well.
There'll be cameras, press, interviews-- I have to protect the picture.
Mrs Travers! How wonderful to see you. What brings you to--
I'll have a-- uh, replacement sent to your hotel right away.
It's all right, Mrs Travers. It's alright. Mr Banks is going to be all right. I promise.
I am Don DaGradi, the script writer.
Uh. Okay, so this is the rest of your team, Dick and Bob Sherman!
Mrs Trav-- it's a long way to--
A word of advice Mrs Travers, if I may.
Wow. Uhm. It's just that he can't stand being called Mr Disney. We are all on a first name basis here.
We have a whole script to get through. It's gonna be a long day Mrs T.
Exterior. It means the scene is taking place outside.
No, No, Mrs Travers please go ahead.
Alright Ladies and gents, comical poem, suitable for the occasion--
--extemporized and thought up before your very eyes! Alright, here we go--
We do find it helps to have a visual. It's fun!
It does seem strange that Mrs Banks allows her children to spend all of their time with the nanny when she has no job to speak of--
No! Of course not! We just felt that if she had a job it would go some way to explaining--
I want you to hear this.
We were just saying that we'd like to play you the song in the bank.
So you have tuppence? May I be permitted to see it?
No, I want it to feed the birds!
Fiddlesticks boy! Feed the birds and what've you got?
While stand the banks of England.
